docs.lead_paragraph: Beware the roads of Maine from 10 to 11 o'clock on a June night. That is the hour when man meets moose. A new study reports that this is the time when most cars collide with moose in a state that has the most moose in the country. The researchers found that though moose were involved in 15 percent of 22,000 collisions with animals over a five-year period, they caused most of the deaths and more than half the injuries.

headline.main: A Collision Report From Moose-Heavy Maine

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention conducts study on roadway accidents involving moose in Maine; findings show that most likely time to encounter moose on roadway is in June between 10 and 11 o'clock at night; other observations noted; drawing (M)

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: Men who take a drug to reduce hair loss may also be reducing their levels of P.S.A., a marker for prostate cancer. That may sound like a good thing, but while the drug lowers the level of P.S.A., it does not lower the risk of cancer. In fact, a new study reports, doctors could be misled into concluding that a patient's risk is lower than it really is.

headline.main: Hair-Loss Drug May Affect Marker for Cancer

docs.abstract: Dr Anthony V D'Amico of Brigham and Women's Hospital and Dr Claus G Roehrborn of University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center lead study that finds some drugs used to reduce hair loss in men can skew PSA test results and fail to give accurate assessment of prostate cancer risk; research is published in journal Lancet; drawing (M)
